bestBHT.bht: Philippi, as a Roman colony, was a notable frontier garrison against Thrace, a memorial to Augustus' victory, and a miniature resemblance of Rome itself. The strategic decision to wait for the Sabbath allowed Paul and his companions to convene with the Jews and proselytes for worship. Situated on the significant Egnatian Way, a major Roman road linking east and west, Philippi positioned Paul face to face with the power and empire of Rome. His mission was to conquer Europe for Christ and establish His Kingdom, drawing upon the groundwork laid by Alexander and Caesar.

Henry Alford: Philippi was made a colonia by Augustus, as a memorial of his victory over Brutus and Cassius, and as a frontier garrison against Thrace."
A Roman colony was in fact a portion of Rome itself transplanted to the provinces."
The inhabitants of the colonies were Roman citizens, and were still enrolled in one or other of the tribes, and possessed the privilege of voting at Rome.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Their whole stay must have extended to some weeks.
As their rule was to begin with the Jews and proselytes, they did nothing till the time when they knew that they would convene for worship.
Waiting till the Sabbath came round.
Albert Barnes: To the church in this place Paul afterward wrote the Epistle which bears its name.
This whole region had been conquered by the Romans under Paulus Aemilius. By him it was divided into four parts or provinces.

It is a strong confirmation of the fact here stated by Luke, that Philippi had the rank and dignity of Roman colony, as coins are still extant, in which Philippi is distinctly referred to as a colony.
Marvin Vincent: The historical difference between a colony and a free town is, that the free towns were taken into the state from without, while the colonies were offshoots from within."
The idea of a colony was, that it was another Rome transferred to the soil of another country.
The affairs of the colony were regulated by their own magistrates named Dumviri, who took pride in calling themselves by the Roman title of praetors.
Philip Schaff: This city was built on the site of the ancient village Krenides (the fountains), subsequently known as Datos, by Philip of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, who named it after himself.
A Roman colony was a miniature resemblance of the Imperial City, a portion of Rome itself transplanted to the provinces.
Such a city being a colony had received the additional privilege of the 'Jus Italicum,' which assimilated the land to Italy.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul... come from Asia to conquer Europe for Christ, a new Caesar to build the Kingdom of Christ on the work of Alexander and Caesar.
Here Paul is face to face with the Roman power and empire in a new sense.
Philippi was on the Egnatian Way, one of the great Roman roads, that ran from here to Dyrrachium on the shores of the Adriatic, a road that linked the east with the west.
John Gill: which is called Edonis, in which Ptolomy places it
and we were in that city abiding many days
the women they after met with by the river side, were such, at least some of them, who had been converted under their ministry
John Wesley: The first city they came to in that part of Macedonia which was nearest to Asia: in that part which was farthest from it."
The river Strymon ran between them."

bhtAttempts.bht: Philippi, a Roman colony, held great significance as a frontier garrison against Thrace and a memorial to Augustus' victory. It was essentially a piece of Rome transplanted to the provinces, with its inhabitants being Roman citizens with voting privileges. Paul and his companions strategically waited until the Sabbath to convene with the Jews and proselytes for worship. Philippi was situated on the Egnatian Way, an important Roman road that connected the east with the west. As Paul faced the Roman power and empire, he came to conquer Europe for Christ and found himself building the Kingdom of Christ on the foundation laid by Alexander and Caesar. Their stay in Philippi extended to several weeks, during which Paul would later write his Epistle to the church there.

Philippi, a Roman colony, held great significance as a frontier garrison and memorial to Augustus. Paul strategically waited till the Sabbath to convene for worship with the Jews and proselytes. It was on the Egnatian Way, a Roman road linking the east with the west, where Paul, aiming to conquer Europe for Christ, faced the Roman power and empire in a new sense. Their extended stay implied their intention to build the Kingdom of Christ on the work of Alexander and Caesar in this important city.

Philippi, a Roman colony, was of great significance as a frontier garrison against Thrace. It stood as a memorial to Augustus' victory, representing a portion of Rome transplanted to the provinces. The inhabitants enjoyed Roman citizenship and voting privileges. Strategically, Paul and his companions waited for the Sabbath to convene with the Jews and proselytes for worship. Philippi was located on the Egnatian Way, a major Roman road linking the east and west. Here, Paul encountered the Roman power and empire, seeking to establish the Kingdom of Christ on the foundation laid by Alexander and Caesar.

Paul and his companions strategically waited for the Sabbath to convene with the Jews and proselytes for worship. Philippi was situated on the Egnatian Way, a major Roman road that linked the east with the west. As Paul faced the Roman power and empire, he aimed to conquer Europe for Christ, building the Kingdom of Christ on the work of Alexander and Caesar.

Philippi, as a Roman colony, was a notable frontier garrison against Thrace, a memorial to Augustus' victory, and a miniature resemblance of Rome itself. The strategic decision to wait for the Sabbath allowed Paul and his companions to convene with the Jews and proselytes for worship. Situated on the significant Egnatian Way, a major Roman road linking east and west, Philippi positioned Paul face to face with the power and empire of Rome. His mission was to conquer Europe for Christ and establish His Kingdom, drawing upon the groundwork laid by Alexander and Caesar.
